docs.lead_paragraph: Five pharmaceutical companies offered today to negotiate steep cuts in the price of AIDS drugs for Africa and other poor regions afflicted by the disease. The announcement of negotiations, to be held with the World Health Organization and other international aid groups, was made in Geneva. It followed mounting pressure on the companies -- including a personal appeal from the United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, at a special session on AIDS in December -- to make their therapies more accessible in Africa, Asia and other regions devastated by the epidemic.

headline.main: COMPANIES TO CUT COST OF AIDS DRUGS FOR POOR NATIONS

docs.abstract: Five pharmaceutical companies offer to negotiate steep cuts in price of AIDS drugs for Africa and other poor regions afflicted by the disease; companies have been under mounting pressure to make their therapies more accessible in regions devastated by AIDS epidemic; 50 million poor people in developing nations are infected with HIV; companies are expected to agree to cuts of 80 percent and more below their American prices; drug treatments used in United States, triple-therapy 'cocktails' that suppress replication of HIV, can cost up to $15,000 a year; five companies are Boehringer Ingelheim of Germany, Bristol-Myers Squibb and Merck & Co of US, Glaxo Wellcome of Britain, and Hoffmann-La Roche of Switzerland; companies will work with five international agencies: World Health Orgn, World Bank, Unaids, United Nations Children's Fund and United Nations Population Fund (M)
docs.snippet: Five pharmaceutical companies offered today to negotiate steep cuts in the price of AIDS drugs for Africa and other poor regions afflicted by the disease.    The announcement of negotiations, to be held with the World Health Organization and other...

keywords.value: INTERNATIONAL BANK FOR RECONSTRUCTION AND DEVELOPMENT

docs.lead_paragraph: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that an antibiotic he was taking to treat an infection after a biopsy of his prostate made him uncomfortable during a speech. ''I'm going to take my jacket off,'' Mr. Giuliani said suddenly in the middle of remarks yesterday afternoon to a conference of mayors at the Grand Hyatt New York City. ''I feel very, very, ah -- I feel warm. Probably because I'm taking medicine. But I'm O.K. I'm not going to faint.''

headline.main: Medicine Causing Discomfort, Mayor Says During Speech

docs.abstract: Mayor Rudolph W Giuliani, in speech to conference of mayors, says that an antibiotic he is taking to treat an infection after biopsy of his prostate makes him uncomfortable (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Forty years ago today, the Food and Drug Administration approved a medication that set off a medical and social revolution. The medication was an oral contraceptive called Enovid, introduced in 1960 by Searle to a nation of women increasingly eager for greater certainty in preventing unwanted pregnancies. Though few realized it then, ''the Pill,'' as it came to be called, has turned out to have a number of ancillary health benefits as well as some serious side effects.

headline.main: The Pill at 40: New Uses for a Drug That Changed Society

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on 40th anniversary of Food and Drug Administration approval of birth control pill; notes women can now choose from 59 different products, all variations on original theme; holds current formulations are remarkably safe; cites side effects and health benefits; photo (M)
